awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of an Airborne Stabilized Platform for InfraRed Experiments (ASPIRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The main purpose of this three-year MRI project is to design and build a solar-tracking platform for the NSF/NCAR Gulfstream-V (GV) aircraft, and demonstrate its capabilities by flying two focal plane instruments during the 2020 total solar eclipse across South America.   The Airborne Stabilized Platform for InfraRed Experiments (ASPIRE) builds on the success of the Airborne InfraRed Spectrometer (AIR-Spec), turning the GV into a solar-viewing platform for rapid prototyping of solar and atmospheric instruments.  By adding a stabilized solar feed to the GV aircraft, the project team will create an airborne platform for infrared remote sensing that will be a valuable resource for both the solar and atmospheric communities.  In solar physics, the 20cm feed would enable many applications on and off the solar disk.  During the upcoming eclipse mission, for example, the ASPIRE will provide enough throughput to make polarimetric measurements with an airborne version of the Coronal Multichannel Polarimeter (CoMP).  The project team will deliver the ASPIRE interface documentation to NSF and NCAR in first quarter 2021.  The ASPIRE project will provide research training for at least three REU students at the Smithsonian Institution Astrophysical Observatory (SAO) over its lifetime.  The team will involve a Boston-based undergraduate in the ASPIRE development and bring this student to Chile to participate in various EPO activities.  Summer test flights in 2020 and 2021 will provide field testing experience for two REU students.  Combining a total solar eclipse with the GV research aircraft is an excellent way to captivate public interest.  As both the 2019 and 2020 eclipses cross South America, the SAO and NCAR staff will reach out to U.S. Embassy personnel to arrange tours of the unique GV aircraft and give talks on eclipse science.

The main goal of this three-year MRI project is to develop the ASPIRE, which will provide a 20cm diameter solar feed, stabilized to <5 arcsec RMS over a 3 second exposure time.  The platform is well-suited for infrared investigations of the Sun, as it can operate above the influence of Earth's atmosphere, and for atmospheric measurements of trace gases obtained by observing sunlight transmitted through atmospheric absorption bands.  The ASPIRE will provide broadband visible and infrared transmission from 0.45 to 10 microns, compatible with all of the GV's IR-transmissive viewports.  During its 2020 commissioning flight, ASPIRE will feed a 13cm telescope with two complementary focal plane instruments: AIR-Spec (an imaging spectrometer) and a new narrowband imager centered on the AIR-Spec 1.43 micron Si X line. AIR-Spec was designed to characterize five magnetically sensitive coronal emission lines between 1.4 and 4 microns and assess whether they are useful probes of coronal magnetism.  It observed all five of its target lines during the 2017 total solar eclipse, detecting the 2.84 micron Fe IX for the first time.  The strong Si X line was observed up to 0.6 solar radii from the limb and provided line-of-sight velocity measurements with a resolution of 5 km/s. The larger telescope aperture enabled by ASPIRE will improve the AIR-Spec SNR by a factor of 1.5 compared to its 2019 observation (>6x improvement over 2017), allowing the project team to explore the coronal density and temperature measurements, flows, and oscillations that are on the edge of detection with the current AIR-Spec instrumentation.  The Si X context imager will reduce the need for rastering the slit, allowing us to improve SNR by summing 'sit and stare' slit data for more than a minute.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Introduction

The goal of this project was to create a 20-cm (7.9-inch) stabilized solar-tracking platform for the NSF/NCAR Gulfstream V (GV) aircraft. We succeeded in building this platform, called ASPIRE (Airborne Stabilized Platform for InfraRed Experiments), and we demonstrated its 6-arcsec RMS stabilization performance by tracking the Sun and Moon in flight. ASPIRE is now available for use by any team in need of an airborne stabilized imaging platform. The Sun-tracking algorithm can be adapted to other targets.

ASPIRE is an extension of our successful NSF-funded Airborne InfraRed Spectrometer (AIR-Spec) missions to the 2017 and 2019 total eclipses. With ASPIRE, we built on those successes to create a more versatile platform with larger diameter, permitting the user to point to various azimuth and elevation angles with greater sensitivity and a minimum of customization. By removing the burden of image stabilization, ASPIRE reduces the development time for new focal plane instruments for the GV.

 

Commissioning Flights

ASPIRE was originally scheduled to be commissioned during the December 14, 2020 total eclipse over South America, but the deployment was canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. NCAR was also forced to cancel the second commissioning flight, scheduled for the December 4, 2021 eclipse over Antarctica. Instead, ASPIRE was commissioned in December 2021 with three flights out of Broomfield, CO.

Figure 1 shows ASPIRE mounted in the GV with its subsystems and focal plane instruments labeled. Image stabilization is provided by a 30-cm gimballed steering mirror, gyroscope, and dedicated high-speed visible light camera. A periscope adapts the beam height to the focal plane instruments. During its commissioning flight, ASPIRE fed two first-light instruments: AIR-Spec with a larger telescope, and a new narrowband imager designed to observe plasma of two different temperatures in the solar corona. 

Figure 2 shows the path flown on December 8, 2021. The noontime Sun was the target during the northwestward leg of the flight. After about an hour, we turned to the southeast to observe the Moon, a waxing crescent at the time. Images of the Sun were used to measure the image stabilization performance. Images and spectra of the Moon were used as a proxy for the eclipse observations and allowed us to validate the focal plane instruments.

 

Image Stabilization Performance

The image stabilization performance was measured using high-framerate (48 fps) images of the Sun from the narrowband imager, one of the two focal plane instruments. This instrument is completely uncoupled from the image stabilization system and therefore provided an independent assessment of that system's performance. The results are shown in Figure 3. Over 30 minutes of flight in smooth air, 92% of one-second exposures were stabilized to better than 6 arcsec RMS. The right-hand plot shows this in a histogram. The left-hand plot shows the improvement afforded by the image stabilization system, compared with no image stabilization. ASPIRE reduces the image jitter by as much as a factor of 50 during the 160-s period shown.

 

Focal Plane Instrument Validation

Because we were unable to deploy to the Falkland Islands to observe the 2021 eclipse, we validated the performance of the two first-light focal plane instruments with observations of the Moon, which is about as bright as the inner corona. This allowed us to check the exposure time and sensitivity of the two instruments. By removing the solar filter and the blur it introduces, we were also able to validate the spatial resolution of the narrowband imager and the spectral resolution of AIR-Spec.

Figure 4 shows an example narrowband image (1393 nm center wavelength, 5 nm bandwidth) taken with an exposure time of 0.1 s. Based on this image, we can expect to observe a few thousand counts per second in future coronal observations made with this instrument. Figure 5 shows example spectra from the bright region where the spectrometer slit crosses the limb of the Moon. The spectrum is of a similar intensity to the coronal spectra observed by AIR-Spec in 2019.

 

Broader Impacts

Although the pandemic canceled our plans for eclipse-related outreach, the creation of ASPIRE provided opportunities for public outreach presentations to the Amateur Telescope Makers of Boston, the Smithsonian's volunteer network, and the general Cambridge-area public during a CfA observatory night. It was featured in presentations to undergraduates at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, at Appalachian State University, and in SAO's summer internship programs. The project supported a one-month internship in data analysis for an undergraduate at Smith College. The commissioning flights were conducted by a team consisting entirely of early/mid-career scientists and engineers, giving these individuals experience with campaign leadership and decision-making. ASPIRE turns the GV into a Sun-pointed, image-stabilized platform for general use by the solar and atmospheric communities.
